thread.title: Flatback turtles in world-first conservation project
thread.title_full: Flatback turtles in world-first conservation project

title: Flatback turtles in world-first conservation project
text:
Map: Bundaberg 4670 
Nine young flatback turtles fitted with tracking tags have been released into the wild off Bundaberg's coast as part of a world-first conservation project. 
The turtles were taken as eggs from Mon Repos beach just over a year ago and were on display at the 2016 World Science Festival in Brisbane when they were just days old. 
The science festival exhibit, called The Hatchery, was stage one of the project, providing an opportunity to educate the public about the protection and conservation of the species. 
The turtles were then raised at Sea Life on the Sunshine Coast, where they could be viewed by the public ahead of their release. 
They are the first young flatback turtles in the world to be tagged with the miniature solar-powered satellite tags, allowing researchers to track their movements and collect important data. 
Sea Life Sunshine Coast general curator Aaron Sprowl said the data would help to uncover the secrets of the turtles' "lost years". Photo: The solar-powered satellite tags will break off after about three months due to the turtles' growth. (ABC Wide Bay: Jess Lodge) 
"They seem to disappear for the first five to 10 years and very little is known about what occurs during this phase," Mr Sprowl said. 
"The data will provide insight into where they go and how they behave, helping us to pinpoint areas of the coast where they congregate." 
Sea Life aquarist Regan Taylor said the data would ultimately be used to assist in the conservation of the vulnerable species. 
"We don't really know much about that life stage so it's really important for us to know where they're going, their feeding grounds and what type of habitats they're wanting to hang out in," she said. 
Flatback turtles are listed as a vulnerable species, and because they stay closer to the coastline than other sea turtles, they tend to be impacted more by dangers such as fishing nets, plastic pollution, boat strikes, habitat loss and coastal development. 
"This program gives us the vital information we need to watch over this species and ensure its long-term survival and sustainability," Mr Sprowl said. Photo: The turtles were raised by these aquarists at Sea Life on the Sunshine Coast. (ABC Wide Bay: Jess Lodge) A bittersweet goodbye 
For the Sea Life staff who raised the turtles, the day of their release was one of mixed feelings. 
"It's going to be sad to say goodbye. But at the same time we're really happy and excited to find out more information about them," aquarist Kaleesha Strickland said. 
"It's very cool to see where they started out from and where they're going to," fellow aquarist Izaac Liley said. 
As the boat came to a stop about 20 kilometres off the coast, the aquarists took it in turns to release the young turtles one by one into the ocean. 
"To be honest I did shed a tear when I released my one," Ms Taylor said. 
"But it's such an awesome feeling to see them back out in the ocean." 
Diver Annie Gray has spent the past year watching the turtles grow and said it was a rewarding moment to watch them swimming away. 
"When you see something grow it's sort of your mothering instinct to protect them and want them to have a good and happy life," Ms Gray said. 
"It's just nice to be putting something back and it's nice to be able to help the species hopefully survive a long time into the future. 
"And if the information we get from this helps us to help the species down the track then it's certainly been completely worthwhile." 
The next group of flatbacks will on display at the World Science Festival in Brisbane in March, before an extended stay at Sea Life.
